title: Haulage boss's wife named as the owner of lorry in which 39 migrants died says they SOLD it
text:
The wife of a haulage boss based in the northwest of England was today named as the owner of the lorry involved in the tragedy by Bulgarian television.

Joanna Maher, 38, from Warrington, was revealed as the keeper of the Scania truck that was registered in the Bulgarian Black Sea port of Varna in 2018.

But Mrs Maher and her husband Thomas last night insisted they sold the lorry cab a year ago to a company in Northern Ireland.

Joanna Maher was named the keep of the Scania truck (pictured above) that was registered to the port of Varna in 2018

She said: 'We did own it but sold it 13 months ago.

'It's the cab - my name was down as owning it.'

They claim they sold it to a company in County Monaghan, close to where truck driver Mo Robinson, 25, lives.

Mrs Maher and her husband Thomas last night insisted they sold the lorry cab a year ago (Varna Marina above)

Mr Maher said he sold it on 3 October last year. He said the couple owned it for just a year.

Thomas said: 'It's disgusting what's happened.

'I went to the British police as we were the registered owners in Bulgaria. I phoned them myself.

The couple said they sold the lorry to a company near to where Mo Robinson (above) lives

'They were happy we had come forward. They are well aware of who they are dealing with.

'It's not nice to be associated with this. We're shocked.'

The couple have three children - two boys aged 18 and 11, and a 15-year-old girl.

They own two Grey Range Rovers - one with a personalised number plate - and a white Chevrolet sports car.

They purchased their detached modern £250,000 home in Warrington, Cheshire two years ago.

Mrs Maher registered the vehicle at a run down 10-storey building in the seaside resort of Varna.

The lorry which carried the refrigerated unit holding 39 bodies left the day after it was registered and has never been back to Bulgaria.

Bulgarian officials believe that there may be no other connection to the country, other than the PO Box and registration certificate.

One resident of the number seven building in Varna said: 'There have been many, many companies using that small office for business here.

'It is locked up now. I have never seen anybody there. The letters used to be put up against the wall and somebody would have to come and collect them. It has been secured and is disused.'
description: Joanna Maher, 38, from Warrington, was named as the keeper of the Scania truck that was registered in the Bulgarian Black Sea port of Varna in 2018.
